page.title: 03MARTINSHAW WOOD,GROBY.
page.content: This historical wood,mentioned in the original Domesday Book,has come under the threat of development in recent times.It lies west of Groby and to the north of Ratby and covers an area of some 254 acres and contains approximately one million trees. Prehistoric and Medieval earthworks still exist as does evidence of the county's only remaining Medieval charcoal burning site.The Forestry Commission bought the wood in 1950 and four years later began an extensive planting programme which lasted until 1969.This involved the planting of over half a million trees,mainly conifers.Some of the old wood survives and this helps to boost the total number of tree species to 36.The wood was bisected by the M1 in 1966 and this with the conifer planting has lessened scientific interest.
